CatDescriptText: Mr. Harry Lantz, statistician, Oakmont and Mr. Olis Eaglin, student, 1843 Wylie Avenue, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 3, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Relative to the race riot in Montgomery, Ala., do you think the Federal Government should wait until a state asks for law enforcement help, or should the power of the United States be used immediately to protect a citizen's life when it is endangered?" Mr. Lantz's answer reads: "Personally, I believe the Government should intervene to protect the rights of citizens, regardless of whether or not there is a request...the state government is not always in the position to protect rights.  And incidentally, I don't see why there has to be riots in the South.  Things should be like they are here, where people of different races get together and settle differences amiably." Mr. Eaglin's answer reads: "The Federal Government should step in right away because in some states, Governors like those in Alabama and Arkansas may be biased."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Harry Lantz wearing eyeglasses and necktie, standing in front of stone building with decorative trim; Portrait of Olis Eaglin wearing eyeglasses and cap, standing in front of stone building with decorative trim
